x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.potential_impact:
PrepperNet builds a voluntary, anonymized map of community preparedness resources.

Citizens can register their preparedness assets (e.g., “I have a generator,” “I can host 2 people,” “I have medical training”) with privacy controls.

Authorities can request aggregated, anonymous insights (e.g., “20 shelters in the local area”).

In emergencies, verified organizations can reach out securely to nearby volunteers or shelter owners.

Impact:
Creates a real-time community resilience network without compromising privacy — empowering local cooperation instead of isolated survivalism.
x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement:
In many regions, individuals prepare for disasters by building shelters, storing supplies, or owning backup power sources — but this information stays private. During real emergencies, this lack of transparency means potential life-saving resources remain unused.
At the same time, most communities have no clear local resilience overview: Where are safe shelters nearby? Who has access to generators or medical kits? How can we coordinate help before chaos hits?
There’s no unified, privacy-respecting system to map or connect community preparedness assets.
x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

App Engine Studio – to create registration and asset management interfaces.

Flow Designer – for automated emergency notifications or data anonymization.

Now Experience UI Builder – for the “Resilience Map” dashboard.

IntegrationHub – to integrate with public safety or GIS APIs.

Performance Analytics – to visualize preparedness coverage across regions.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Mapping API (e.g., Google Map) for location clustering.

Optional integration with municipal emergency management systems.

Secure identity and role-based access control to manage data visibility.

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Privacy and data sensitivity around personal shelters and resources.

Verification of users claiming to have certain assets or capabilities.

Balancing anonymity with usefulness in real emergencies.

Building community trust to encourage participation.

Making the information available offline in case of a power outage and internet shutdown.
